title: 111_hr2030
content: The Act may be cited as the "Senator Paul Simon Water for the World Act of 2009". The Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005 aims to improve access to safe water and sanitation in developing countries through specific policy objectives and assistance programs. It also aligns with the United Nations Millennium Development Goals to reduce water-related issues by half between 1990 and 2015. The United Nations General Assembly declared 2008 as the International Year of Sanitation to recognize the impact of sanitation on public health, poverty reduction, and social development. Congress passed H. Con. Res. 318 in August 2008 to support the goals of the International Year of Sanitation and acknowledge the importance of sanitation on public health and economic development. The lack of access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation services affects over 884 million people worldwide. Unsafe water and poor sanitation account for nearly 10% of the global burden of disease and over 2 million deaths annually. Climate change is expected to worsen water availability for 2.8 billion people in the future. The future management of water resources is a growing concern, with 2.8 billion people in over 48 countries facing severe shortages by 2025. Reports predict that rapid urbanization, population growth, and climate change will exacerbate water access issues, particularly in agriculture-based economies. The effects of climate change are projected to lead to long-term droughts and rising sea levels for the next 1,000 years. The United Nations reports that over 1/5 of the world population relies on polluted or excessively withdrawn freshwater. Water scarcity has led to conflicts in regions like Darfur, Sudan. To address these challenges, the United States must expand foreign assistance for safe water and sanitation efforts. The United States should lead a global effort to provide sustainable access to clean water and sanitation for poor people worldwide. The purpose of this Act is to provide first-time access to safe water and sanitation for 100,000,000 people by 2015 and enhance the capacity of the US Government to implement related legislation. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to establish the Office of Water within the United States Agency for International Development. The office will be headed by a Director for Safe Water and Sanitation, responsible for implementing water-related legislation and developing country-specific water programs. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to establish the Office of Water within the United States Agency for International Development. The office will develop country-specific water strategies to provide sustainable access to safe water and sanitation for 100,000,000 additional people by 2015. Emphasis will be on safe, affordable, and sustainable drinking water, sanitation, and hygiene. The Director may utilize partnerships with universities, civil society, and the private sector to strengthen implementation capacity. A Special Coordinator for International Water will be established to address international issues regarding safe water, sanitation, and integrated river basin management. The Special Coordinator for Global Affairs oversees and coordinates US diplomatic policy on global freshwater issues, including safe drinking water access, river basin management, transboundary conflicts, water resource productivity, disaster response, pollution mitigation, and adaptation to hydrologic change. The Special Coordinator for Global Affairs oversees US diplomatic policy on global freshwater issues, including adaptation to hydrologic change due to climate variability. They are authorized to hire staff to carry out their duties. SEC. 6. SAFE WATER, SANITATION, AND HYGIENE STRATEGY. In amending the Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005, the Secretary is required to consider assessment results in developing program activities. Additionally, an assessment of US foreign assistance for drinking water and sanitation in the past 3 fiscal years is mandated. The Secretary is required to assess US Government efforts to provide safe water and sanitation to 100,000,000 people in high priority countries. Recommendations for achieving these goals in support of the United Nations' Millennium Development Goal on safe drinking water are also needed. Additionally, best practices for forming public-private partnerships to increase access to safe drinking water and sanitation should be assessed. SEC. 7 of the Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005 is amended to include a new section on water and sanitation institutional capacity-building program. The Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005 is amended to establish a program in high priority countries to build capacity for water and sanitation institutions. The program established under the Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005 aims to provide sustainable access to safe drinking water and sanitation in high priority countries. It includes educating populations about the dangers of unsafe water, promoting behavior change to reduce disease risks, and coordinating programs through lead country water managers. The Secretary and Administrator may expand the program to additional countries for capacity building in promoting access to safe drinking water. The Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005 aims to promote access to safe drinking water and sanitation in high priority countries. The program includes capacity building, strategic objectives, and partnerships with various entities to strengthen implementation capacity. The Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005 designates safe drinking water and sanitation as a strategic objective. It appoints a USAID employee as in-country water and sanitation manager to coordinate implementation with host country officials and relevant US government agencies. Coordination with the Development Credit Authority and Global Development Alliance is also required. SEC. 8. OTHER ACTIVITIES SUPPORTED. Section 135(c) of the Foreign Assistance Act is amended to include fostering global cooperation on research and technology development for water-related issues, establishing regional and cross-border cooperative activities, and providing grants through the United States Agency for International Development. SEC. 9. UPDATED REPORT REGARDING WATER FOR PEACE AND SECURITY. The report shall include an assessment of political tensions over water sources and impacts of climate change on water supplies in the future. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2009 and subsequent years to carry out the Act and amendments. Up to 20% of funds can be used for general water resource management, with the rest allocated for activities related to safe drinking water, sanitation, and hygiene.
